section-block.rac_essential-question: What are the parts of our bodies? What do they do?

section-block.rac_book_title_byline: Written by Connie Schofield-Morrison and illustrated by Frank Morrison
section-block.rac_book_summary: This story is about a little girl who hears a rhythm and is soon clapping and snapping and tipping and tapping! You’ll get the rhythm, too!

section-block.rac_copyright_line: 978-1-338-64874-4. TM ® & © Scholastic Inc. All rights reserved. I Got the Rhythm by Connie Schofield-Morrison, illustrated by Frank Morrison. Text copyright © 2014 by Connie Schofield-Morrison. Illustrations copyright © 2014 by Frank Morrison. Published by Scholastic Inc. by arrangement with Bloomsbury Children’s Books USA.

section-block.rac_body-text: Introduce patterns by going around the circle having children alternate between saying “hi” and “bye” in turn. Explain that this is an ABAB pattern. Repeat with AABB.
Create a simple rhythm by clapping your hands in a steady beat and having the children repeat it. Increase the tempo and have the children repeat each rhythm faster.

section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: This week we are going to read I Got the Rhythm by Connie Schofield-Morrison and illustrated by Frank Morrison.
Lala the Lizard loves reading stories that show patterns. In this story, we see and hear patterns.
There’s a question I want you to think about as we read: What body parts are named in this story?

section.rac_body-text: Use Equity Sticks to choose children to answer questions.
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Who remembers what rhythm means? We are going to read about a girl who finds rhythms everywhere. She even makes rhythms with her body!
The girl thinks a rhythm.
Think about the clapping rhythm we made. Who has a rhythm in their head? How does it go?
Now the girl hears a rhythm with her ears. Who hears a rhythm when I say “beat, beat”? What’s a rhythm you have heard?
Now the girl smells a rhythm. She sniffs it with her nose. What smell do you think she sniffs from the picture?
The rhythm goes “clap clap” and then “snap snap.” What is the pattern in “clap, clap, snap, snap”?
Some of these words have sounds that are the same in the beginning or end of the word. What pattern can you find in these sounds?
Let’s talk about the guiding question: What body parts are named in this story?
section.rac_body-text: Give children time to Turn and Talk. Then use Equity Sticks to choose several children to share.
Write and read aloud short sentences about the parts of the body that can create a rhythm as children watch.

rac_support_challenge-box.rac_teacher-talk_blue: What body part does the girl use to sing?
She uses her m____ (mouth) to sing.
She uses her mouth to sing.
How does the girl use the body part you named?

section-block.rac_child_development_body: Children can recognize, create, and copy simple patterns on their own, even before they know the word pattern. To identify and extend more complex patterns, children do best with the guidance of an adult helping them see and understand the patterns.

section-block.rac_column_heds_no_paragraph_rule_day_2: Share the Mind Builder: Engage with Adults and Peers
section-block.rac_body-text: Explain to children that engaging is talking, playing, or working with other people, adults or children. You might talk with other people to learn more about them. You might work with other people when you play. For example, when you build train tracks with your friends. Ask children to share examples of working together.

section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Today we will reread some pages of I Got the Rhythm by Connie Schofield-Morrison and illustrated by Frank Morrison. We will look for ways the girl works with adults and peers to find rhythm.
Clifford loves to play and work with his peers. He also enjoys rhythms with his friends when creating, singing and dancing!

section.rac_column_heds_with_rule: Close-Read: Connect to the Mind Builder
section.rac_body-text: Focus on Patterns: Ask children, “what is the pattern” as you encounter patterns in the book.
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Let’s reread and talk about some pages of the book to see how the girl works with others to make and find rhythms.
The girl hears the rhythm. The rhythm is coming from someone making noises that go “beat beat.” Can you make a pattern of beats?
The girl is clapping the rhythm with another girl. How do they work together to make a rhythm? (MB)
Is the girl working with anyone else here? What kind of pattern do they make together? (MB)
How is the group working together? How might more people make dancing easier? (MB)
She taps a tip tap rhythm. Tip tap, tip tap. What kind of patten do you hear in the rhythm?

section.rac_body-text: Explain to children that the whole group is going to build a musical pattern together using their body parts.

Alternate two different body parts in an ABAB pattern. Demonstrate each part of the pattern and have the children repeat it. Then, make the entire pattern and have the group repeat it. Keep repeating the pattern, with the group repeating it after you, until the children have it.
Increase the tempo and help the children adjust. Keep increasing the tempo, giving the children time to adjust until the tempo is too fast to maintain and becomes silly.
Transcribe children’s speech as they name the body parts that make the rhythms in the book’s pictures.

section-block.rac_child_development_body: Positive interactions can have a strong impact on educational outcomes. Children can form a base for having positive interactions by trying to understand situations they observe. Encourage children to build a base for engaging with adults and peers by having them start by asking questions like “why is that child doing that?” (Zigler, Gilliam, Jones; 2006).

section-block.rac_body-text: Help children understand that adding or taking away one from a small group of objects changes the total quantity by one. Play “Spot the Mistake.” Show 3 or 4 objects. Count aloud, add one more or take one away, and then state the total. Sometimes say the correct total and sometimes make a mistake. Guide children to say whether you are right. Always ask children to count to confirm the correct total.
Sing the Hokey Pokey with the children, modeling how to put one body part in the circle at a time. Guide them to bring it out and in again, then shake it.

section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Today we are going to reread I Got the Rhythm by Connie Schofield-Morrison and illustrated by Frank Morrison.
Lala loves stories like this one because she can use the sounds and body parts in the story to make pattens!
The girl in the story uses parts of her body to make a rhythm. As we read today, I want you to think about this guiding question: How does the girl use her body parts to make a rhythm?

section.rac_body-text: Help children practice adding one or taking one away from a small set of numbers while learning about body parts. Use counters for support.
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: What body part is the girl using? How many eyes do you have?
How many if I take one counter away?
Now she smells the rhythm with her nose. Point to your nose. How many noses would you have if you had one more nose?
She sings with her mouth. Can you sing a simple pattern with your mouth like, “mm bop mm bop”?
What body parts do the girls clap with? How many hands do they each have? How many hands would they use if the girl used two hands and her friend used one hand? (MB)
Where are your fingers? How many do you have on one hand?
Did you think about the question as we read the story today?
section.rac_guiding-question_blue: How does the girl use her body parts to make a rhythm?
section.rac_body-text: Have children Turn and Talk. Use Equity Sticks to ask several children to respond to the guiding question.
section.rac_body-text_bulleted: She feels a rhythm with her knees.
She sees a rhythm with her eyes.
She shakes a rhythm with her hips.

section.rac_body-text: Share a pen with children as you draw and write together about how people use different parts of the body to express a rhythm.

rac_support_challenge-box.rac_teacher-talk_blue: What does she use to clap a rhythm?
She claps a rhythm with her h____ (hands).
She claps a rhythm with her hands.
How do you make a rhythm with the same body parts?

section-block.rac_child_development_body: Children can build off the counting groundwork they have of their foundational understanding of counting by adding or taking away one from a small group. Help supplement children’s natural ability to add and subtract by practicing increasing and decreasing amounts by one throughout the day.

section-block.rac_column_heds_no_paragraph_rule_day_4: Talk About Parts of the Body
section-block.rac_body-text: Lead children in a discussion of the body parts mentioned in the book. How can we use each of these body parts to help us express rhythm? Are there other parts of the body we can use to create a rhythm? What are they? How can we use those body parts to create a rhythm?

section.rac_column_heds_no_paragraph_rule: Share the Big Chart of Big Ideas
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: This week we are going to read Head, Shoulder, Knees, and Toes. It is a poster with an action song.
I Got the Rhythm and Head, Shoulders, Knees, and Toes both focus on parts of the body. Let’s look for connections as we read!
section.rac_hilight_teacher_inst_new: Show I Got the Rhythm book cover.

section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: What are the parts of our bodies? What do they do?

section.rac_body-text: Review the lyrics with children. Stand and perform the song and actions together.
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: In I Got the Rhythm does the girl create a rhythm with her head? How can we make a rhythm with our heads?
In I Got the Rhythm does the girl create a rhythm with her shoulders? How can we make a rhythm with our shoulders?
The picture points out eye, ear, mouth, and nose. The eyes, ears, mouth, and nose are all on the face. Can you make a rhythm with these body parts? What do we use these body parts for?
Your knees are in the middle of your legs. How many knees do you have on one leg? How many do you have total?

section.rac_body-text: As a class, make up new lyrics for the song using four different body parts, such as hands, fingers, hips, and feet. Make up movements to match the song. Perform the new song and actions together. (MB)
Provide a writing prompt about a part of the body, and give feedback as children draw and write in response to the prompt.

section-block.rac_child_development_hed-green: Child Development: Pointing to Parts of the Body
section-block.rac_child_development_body: Singing songs like Head, Shoulders, Knees, and Toes helps children learn coordination, vocabulary, and fine motor skills. Children gain a better awareness of what their body can do and how it works when you play games that challenge them to try movements like touching their right hand to their left knee.

section-block.rac_body-text: Invite children to suggest songs the group can sing. Children should sing the song once, and then sing it again, clapping the rhythm of the song as they sing.
Pick a rhythm leader. This person will make a pattern of rhythmic motions that the rest of the group will follow. For example, the leader might clap, then snap, then stomp.

Everyone else in the group will follow the pattern the rhythm leader sets until they are all doing it together with the same timing. Then, use Equity Sticks to choose a new leader to model a new rhythm.

section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Today we are going to retell and reenact the book I Got the Rhythm by Connie Schofield-Morrison and illustrated by Frank Morrison.
This story is a narrative, which means it isn’t a true story. But a story like this could be real. Lala likes stories like this because she likes to pretend she is in the story.
We read about how different parts of our body can be used to express a rhythm. When we read today, I want you to think about this question:
section.rac_guiding-question_blue: Which body part do you like to use to make a rhythm?

section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Let’s reread the book one more time together. This time, our friends will act out the rhythm as we read.
The girl smells the rhythm with her nose. Let’s all smell a rhythm with our noses!
Let’s all sing the “ooh la la” rhythm with our mouths!
Now the girl shakes the rhythm with her hips. Let’s all shake a rhythm with our hips!
Let’s all knock a rhythm with our knees!
Let’s all out act walking a rhythm with our feet. I’ll start the rhythm. Follow me! (MB)
Did you listen and remember as we read the story today? Which body part do you like to use to make a rhythm?
section.rac_body-text: Ask children to Turn and Talk about the guiding question. Use Equity Sticks to choose several children to respond.
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Possible responses:
section.rac_body-text_bulleted: I like to snap with my fingers.
I like to sing with my mouth.
I like to tap with my toes.

section.rac_body-text: Invite children to draw or write a story about what body part makes the best rhythm.

rac_support_challenge-box.rac_teacher-talk_blue: What body part do you use if you like to stomp?
I like to stomp with my f__ (feet).
I like to stomp with my feet.
Why do you like using that body part to make a rhythm?

section-block.rac_child_development_body: Help multilingual learners to feel more comfortable in the class and help other children connect with different cultures and languages by making some activities a “two-way street.” When teaching about music, invite multilingual learners to share a song from their home culture and have the class sing it together.
